For evaluating the lifespan of tyres of a particular brand, the distances (in km) driven before the tyres were worn out were recorded for a random sample of $100$ cars. 
The data was agregated in a frequency table shown below. Which statement is true? 

$\begin{array}{ |c|c|} 
\hline
\text{Kilometers}&\text{Frequency} \\ 
\hline
0 -30 000& 15\\ 
30 001 - 60 000 & 25\\ 
60 001 - 90 000 & 60\\ 
 \hline
\end{array}$
answer1: The sample range is at least $30 001$ but at most $90 000$.
answer3: The sample range is at least $30 000$ but  at most $90 000$.

question:
Four workers ($W_1$, $W_2$, $W_3$ and $W_4$) should be selected to perform three different tasks ($T_1$, $T_2$ and $T_3$), for which they are unequally prepared. Based on the qualifications and previous experience, it was possible to construct the following table which indicates, for each worker $j$, the operation time in each task  $i$ (in weeks):
	
\[
\begin{array}{l|cccc|}
& W_1 & W_2 & W_3 & W_4 \\
\hline
T_1 & 2 & 6 & 7 & 4 \\
T_2 & 9 & 8 & 4 & 2 \\
T_3 & 2& 7 & 5 & 7 \\
\hline 
\end{array}
\]	

Supposing that the several tasks start at same time, what workers should be selected to complete all the three tasks as soon as possible?

question:
Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{C}^2\right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
(1+i)z& + & (1-i)w & = & i \\
(1-i)z& + & (1+i)w & = & 1-i
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The unique solution of the linear system is $\bigg(\frac{3+i}{4},-\frac{1+i}{4}\bigg)$.
answer2: The solutions of the linear system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{1+i}{4},\frac{-1+i}{4}+z\bigg)$, for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has the vector $(i,-i)$ has its unique solution.

Given a number $n \geq 1$, it can be represented as the following array of length $n$:
$$n = (1,\, 1,\, 1,\, 1,\, \dots,\, 1)$$
Suppose we are playing a game in which at each step we can advance one entry or two entries of the array. This leads us to a way of representing $n$ as a sum of natural numbers.

As an example, consider $n=5$ and the steps $1,\, 2,\, 2$. Then we get

$5 = (1 $ $\color{red} |$ $ 1 + 1 $ $\color{red} | $ $ 1 + 1)$, this is, $5 = 1 + 2 + 2$.

Note we are considering that, for example, $5 = 1+2+2$ is different from $5 = 2+1+2$.

answer2: $(1,1)$ is a saddle point and $(0,0)$ is a minimum.
answer3: $(1,1)$ and $(-1,-1)$ are a saddle points and $(0,0)$ is a minimum.
answer4: $(1,1)$ and $(-1,-1)$ are minima and $(0,0)$ is a saddle point.

For each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, describe the solutions of the linear system
$$\begin{cases}
3x & + & y & - & z & = & 1 \\
x & - & 2y & - & z & = & m \\
x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
For $m=-2$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m \neq -2$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer2: The linear system has no solution for every $m\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
For $m \in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m=0$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(0,\,1,\,1\right)$.
For $m \not\in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has a unique solution for each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, which is $\left(0,\,m,\,m-1\right)$.

question:

$\frac{2x}{4}=3x^3$

At the HealthPlus hospital, the nursing staff works in $6$ different shifts. Each shift has a duration of $8$ hours, with its start interval of $4$ hours (the first shift starts at $8:00$ AM, the second at $12:00$ AM, the third at $4:00$ p.m., and so on). The number of nurses required during the day is in the following table. How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning the nursing staff, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of nurses working in shift $i~(i = 1~to~6)$?

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|}
\hline
\text{Day period} & \text{Required number of nurses} \\
\hline
\text{8:00 a.m. to 12:00 a.m.} & 140 \\
\text{12:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.} & 120 \\
\text{4:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.} & 160 \\
\text{8:00 p.m. to 12:00 p.m.} & 90 \\
\text{12:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m.} & 30 \\
\text{4:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m.} & 60 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]
answer2:
\[
		\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^5 x_{i}\\			
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 120\\			
		& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\
		&x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\
		&x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\
		&x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~5\\ 
		\end{array}
	     \]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
			\text{Maximize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 120\\
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 60\\
			& x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~6\\
			\end{array}
			\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll} 
				\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\			
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+x_{6}\geq 140\\			
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\			
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\			
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\			
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 60\\
			\end{array}
			\]

\end{cases}$$

Find the solution of the following system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &-1 \\ 
&x &+ &y &- &5z &= &2
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3},y, -\frac{1}{3}\right),\, \forall y\in\mathbb{R}$$.
answer2:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3}z,y, z\right),\, \forall y,z\in\mathbb{R}$$.

answer2: The system has $\left(0,\,1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.

Consider the function $f(x,y)=\dfrac{x-y^{4}}{x^{3}-y^{4}}$, where $y^{4} \neq x^{3}$.

Study the limits
$\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]$, $\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]$ and $\lim\limits_{ (x,y)\rightarrow (1,1)}f(x,y).$
answer1:
$\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=\frac{1}{3}$, $\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=1$, but the limit
$\lim\limits_{ (x,y)\rightarrow (1,1)}f(x,y)$ does not exist.
answer2:
$\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=1$, but the limit
$\lim\limits_{ (x,y)\rightarrow (1,1)}f(x,y)$ does not exist.

question:
A consulting firm will carry out two types of projects ($A$ and $B$). The development cost per project $A$ and $B$ is, respectively, $1$ and $2$ monetary units. The requirements in terms of analysts, programmers and terminals for each type of project are indicated in the following table:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Project} & \text{N. of programmers}  & \text{N. of analysts}  & \text{N. of terminals} \\
\hline
\text{A} & 2 & 2 & 3 \\
\text{B} & 3 & 6 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

The company wants to minimize the cost of developing projects in the next period. In the development of these projects, at least $10$ programmers and $5$ analysts should be used while the company only has $6$ terminals available. How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized  to allow planning the company's activity?

Find the partial derivatives of the function $z(x,y)=x^4 e^{y^5}$.
answer1: $\dfrac{\partial z}{\partial x}(x,y)=4x^3 e^{y^5}, \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial y}(x,y)=5x^4y^4 e^{y^5} $
answer2: $\dfrac{\partial z}{\partial x}(x,y)=4x^5 e^{y^4}, \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial y}(x,y)=x^4 e^{y^5} y^4$
answer3: $\dfrac{\partial z}{\partial x}(x,y)=3x^3 e^{y^5}, \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial y}(x,y)=x^4 e^{y^5} 5y$
answer4: $\dfrac{\partial z}{\partial x}(x,y)=x^3 e^{y^5}, \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial y}(x,y)=x^4 e^{y} 5y^4$
